answers.answer: This may be early subclinical hypothyroidism -- a trial of thyroid hormone may be helpful -- testing antibodies to see if this is Hashimoto's would be reasonable.  There is no data for or against treatment in this scenario.

Hi Renee,I am 47 and for 21/2 years have had intermittant symptoms as you mentioned above. It seemed it would last for weeks to months and then get better, but always tired.  My TSH's were simuliar to yours.  I went to an "older" endo who ignored the TSH's and read then as normal.  He suggested I go to Mayo Clinic.  After that I found an article posted by the American Association of Clinical Endocrinolgist which recommends that a TSH > 3.03 be evaluated for treatment and that each case should be individualized but certainly if there are symptoms you could benefit.  That was in December.  I took this info to my family practice who started me on 25mcg synthyroid.  After 8 weeks I was back to my old self and very excited.  Unfortunately now in April I have started having some of the same symptoms, but not near as bad.  I do feel hormones are the culprit.  But probabIy a combination of thyroid and adrenal.  I hope this helps you in getting prepared for your visit.  You may meet resistance, but don't give up. Somethings are standard but others differ from one physician to another and you have to just find the right physican for you.  Good luck and please post what kind of response you get from him.   Also see these sites:http://www.aace.com/newsroom/press/2003/index.php?r=20030118and     http://thyroid.about.com/cs/testsforthyroid/a/labs2003.htmHope this helps,          Judy
Thanks you for your assistance and advise.

question: Dr. Lupo,I'm a 42 yr old female.  For about 6 years I've been complaining to my doctor about the following symptoms.  The symptoms are progressively getting worse and I desperately need help.  The quality of my life has gone down and if I continue on this track I’m going to lose my job.•	Extreme fatigue and body ache•	Continuous slight headache•	Chills•	Sleeplessness at night but tired during the day•	Can’t think clearly.  Forget what I’m saying.  Forget names easily.•	Extremely dry skin•	Weight keeps rising even though I am continuously dieting•	Swollen eye lids with black bags under my eyes (doc told me allergies but it isn’t allergies because          allergy medicine didn’t help )I had a hysterectomy in 1995 but didn’t begin to gain weight until around 2000.  I have high blood pressure, high cholesterol (290) but HIGH resting heart rate (95-110).  The blood pressure is being controlled by meds.  I refused to continue the cholesterol meds because they caused my muscles to ache even more.  I have a family history of heart disease and diabetes but I don’t have any signs of the diseases.  My mother and sister have hypothyroid but I don’t know what their TSH was prior to being treated.I ordered my lab history because I usually only get a piece of paper back stating that everything is normal.3/27/08  4:10PM    TSH   4.03 (.35-5.50)FT4    1.07 (.61-1.76)FT3    2.7   (2.3-4.2)5/31/07 12:12PM   TSH   3.81 (.35-5.50) No other tests9/29/03  9:42AM    TSH   4.24 (.35-5.50) No other tests5/25/01 11:52AM   TSH   3.09  (.35-5.50) No other testsI have an endo appointment on Monday.  Am I wasting my time?  Is it possible to get the doctor to treat me for subclinical hypothyroidism or does the risk outweigh the benefit?Thanks!  Renee
title: Dr. Lupo - Treatment for Subclinical Hypothyroidism
